titleStmt.title: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of WMoNbCrTi HEAs Sintered from the Powders Milled for Different Durations

analytic.title: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of WMoNbCrTi HEAs Sintered from the Powders Milled for Different Durations

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Refractory high-entropy alloys (HEAs) are reported to have better properties than conventional alloys. In this work, a new refractory WMoNbCrTi HEA was spark plasma sintered with ball milling powder. The results show that the microstructure and mechanical properties of the bulk alloys are strongly dependent on the milling duration of the powders. The structure of the powders milled for 5-40 h is mainly composed of three BCC solid solution phases (W-rich, Nb-rich and Cr-rich). After being consolidated by SPS, the structure of the bulk alloys consists of a W-rich solid solution matrix with a small amount of Ti-rich solid solution and Laves phase. The WMoNbCrTi HEA prepared from 30 h milling powder shows the highest hardness value of 10.40 GPa. However, the alloy prepared from the 5 h milling powder exhibits the maximum fracture toughness (7.16 MPa m 1/2 ), compressive fracture strength (2765 MPa) and fracture strain (9.8%), respectively. The reasons for the influence of the milling duration on the mechanical properties of the WMoNbCrTi HEAs are discussed in detail. The combination of mechanical alloying and the subsequent sintering is a promising way to fabricate HEAs with controllable mechanical properties.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: High-entropy alloys (HEAs) have attracted worldwide interest in the field of materials science and engineering. 1 HEAs were designed according to the principle of an equal-molar or near-equal-molar fraction for all the components, which resulted in high configurational entropy. 2 Generally, HEAs are composed of simple and stable BCC or FCC solid solution phase, or a mixed structure of BCC plus FCC solid solution phases, even a mixed structure of solid solution phases plus precipitation phases, which are well known as the result of a high mixing entropy effect. 3 The excellent mechanical or physicochemical properties of the HEAs, such as high hardness, good fatigue resistance, wear resistance, good oxidation and corrosion resistance, [4][5][6] may meet the increasing demands in the various industrial fields.

The previous investigations of HEAs were mostly focused on the HEA systems with FCC structure, which includes transition metals such as Co, Ni, Fe, Cr and Mn. 2 From 2010 onwards, the refractory HEA systems have been developed for elevatedtemperature application, which predominately consisted of some elements of W, Ta, V, Nb, Mo, Hf, Zr and Ti. 7 The refractory HEAs were originally designed for aerospace applications with promising mechanical behavior at high temperatures. 8,9 For example, hot isostatic pressed TaNbHfZrTi HEA has a Vickers hardness value of 3826 MPa. 10 Refractory NbMoTaW and NbMoTaWV HEAs have compressive yield strength values of 1058 MPa and 1246 MPa at room temperature, 11 respectively. It is also reported that HfMoNbTaTiZr HEA exhibits the compressive yield strength value of 556 MPa at 1200°C. 12 TiZrNbTaMo HEA exhibits apparent JOM https://doi.org/10.1007/s11837-019-03432-9

Ó 2019 The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society plastic strain of $ 6% at room temperature. 13 In view of the above findings, the refractory HEAs are promising structural materials applied to hightemperature environments. Generally, the refractory HEAs prepared by arc melting show an inhomogeneous microstructure, 13 which is usually harmful to their properties. The mechanical alloying (MA) is a conventional method to fabricate various alloys, which could enable alloying between elements with large differences in melting points. 14,15 In addition, spark plasma sintering (SPS) can be used to rapidly sinter HEAs. The spark plasma sintered (SPSed) alloys exhibit a uniform microstructure with fine grains. 16,17 Therefore, MA-SPS is an effective way to fabricate refractory HEAs.

Generally, fabrication of HEAs via powder metallurgical technology includes two steps. The first step is to obtain the alloying powders via high-energy ball milling. The second step is to prepare the bulk HEAs with the alloying powders. For the first step, the previous investigations have mostly focused on how the milling duration influences the alloying degree of the mixed powders. 18,19 In fact, to achieve the homogenized alloying of the powders, contamination from the milling media would occur because of the prolonged milling time. 20 However, it is not necessary to form alloying for the mixed powders during the milling process because the alloying can be achieved through the subsequent sintering process. Namely, the HEAs could be successfully fabricated by sintering the powders milled for a certain time. However, less attention has been paid to the correlation between the mechanical properties of the bulk alloy and the milling duration of the powders. In this work, with the aim to understand the correlation between the milling time of the powders and the mechanical properties of the HEAs, the WMoNbCrTi HEAs were prepared by sintering powders milled for different times. The effect of the milling durations on the microstructure, phase evolution and mechanical properties of the WMoNbCrTi HEAs was investigated.

div.head: MATERIALS AND METHODS
div.p: The raw powders used in our experiments were W (99.9%, 15-30 lm), Nb (99.5%, 20-40 lm), Mo (99.9%, 1-3 lm), Cr (20-40 lm) and Ti (99.9%, 20-40 lm). The HEA powders were designed according to the equiatomic composition and milled in a highenergy planetary ball mill (QM-3SP4, China) with stainless steel grinding media under an Ar atmosphere. The milling speed was 300 rpm, and the ball-to-powder weight ratio was 10:1. The powders milled for different durations (0 h, 5 h, 10 h, 20 h, 30 h and 40 h) were denoted 0-HEs, 5-HEAs, 10-HEAs, 20-HEAs, 30-HEAs and 40-HEAs, respectively. The milled powders were consolidated by SPS (SPS-20T-10, China) in a near vacuum of 10 À3 Pa at 1400°C for 8 min under a pressure of 30 MPa.

The particle size distribution of the ball-milled powders was measured using a laser particle size analyzer (MS2000, Malvern Corp.). The actual densities of the bulk HEAs were measured with the water immersion method based on Archimedes' law. The relative density was calculated with the formula q 1 / q 0 , where q 1 is the actual density and q 0 is the theoretical density. The Vickers hardness (HV) of the samples was measured using a Vickers Hardness Tester (HV-30, China) at a tip speed of 7.5 9 10 À5 m/ s with a load of 98 N and a dwell time of 10 s. Fracture toughness (K IC ) values were also determined by Vickers indentation method. The value of K IC was calculated using the equation given by Anstis et al. 21 Each sample was tested five times at different points, and the average value was regarded as its hardness value or fracture toughness. The compressive tests were performed at room temperature at an engineering strain rate of 10 À3 s À1 with cylindrical samples (U 4 mm 9 6 mm).

The crystalline structure of the powders and the SPSed alloys were investigated by x-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advanced) using Cu Ka radiation. The microstructure morphologies of the powders and the bulk alloys were characterized by scanning electron microscopy equipped with an energy dispersive xray spectrometer (SEM-EDS, JSM-5610L) using both secondary (SE) and backscattered electron (BSE) imagining modes at an acceleration voltage of 20 kV.

div.head: Crystalline Structures and Morphologies of the Milled Powders
div.p: Figure 1 shows the XRD patterns of the milled powders as a function of the milling duration. As the milling time increased from 5 h to 40 h, the diffraction peaks of the Ti and Mo elements became very weak, indicating the Ti and Mo elements had gradually dissolved into the other elements. After 40 h milling, the diffraction peaks of the W, Nb and Cr elements were still obviously detected. It is clear that three BCC solid solution phases, including Wrich, Nb-rich and Cr-rich phases, were formed in the milled powders. Generally, during the MA process, the alloying rate of the multicomponent elements is inversely proportional to the melting point of the element. 22 Ti had the lowest melting point and highest intrinsic diffusion in the W-Mo-Nb-Cr-Ti system, which led to its quicker solid solution than for other elements. Although the melting point of Mo is close to Nb, the brittleness of the Mo led to its quicker solid solution than for Nb. 21 It is interesting that the Nb-rich and Cr-rich solid solution phases were also formed during the MA process. These two metastable solid solution phases will disappear during the subsequent SPS process. Moreover, with continuing milling time, the peak intensity broadened gradually owing to crystal size refinement and lattice strain, as seen in Fig. 1b.

Both the SEM micrographs and the particle size of the powders as a function of the milling times are shown in Fig. 2. It is seen that the micrographs of the powders with increasing milling time exhibit the characteristics of irregularly shaped, layer structure and near-spherical particles. During the MA process, the powders were subjected to plastic deformation, cold welding, fracture and agglomeration. 22,23 The powder micrograph depends on which process is dominant during the milling process. After 5-10 h milling, the plastic deformation of the powders caused the shape change, and the cold welding of the powders increased their average size. The average particle sizes of 5-HEAs and 10-HEAs are 40.6 lm and 64.2 lm, respectively. As the milling time increased up to 20 h, the plastic deformation of the powders nearly diminished, and the brittle fracture became the important process, accompanying the decrease in the particles size. During this stage, the agglomerated powders were subjected to continuous fragmentation to form fine particles. Further increasing the milling duration up to 30-40 h, the brittle fracture and agglomeration of the particles reached equilibrium owing to the expended maximum energy, which led to the average particle size approaching a plateau of about 4.2 lm at 40 h milling time. In addition, the chemical compositions of the particles for different milling times determined by EDS are listed in Table I. As is seen, with increasing the milling time, the concentration distribution of the five elements presented a relative homogeneity and the content of Fe impurity in powders increased gradually.

div.head: Phase and Microstructure of the Sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs
div.p: Figure 3a shows the XRD patterns of the WMoNbCrTi HEAs sintered from the various powders. To investigate the phase evolution during the SPS process, the XRD patterns for the 30 h milling powder and the corresponding bulk sample are comparatively analyzed in Fig. 3b. It is clear that the bulk alloys are composed of two BCC solid solution phases (W-rich and Ti-rich phases) and a Laves phase. The phase amounts estimated using the peak area of XRD are shown in Table II. It is clear that the amount of Laves phase for the 30-HEAs reached the maximum value of 3.92 wt.%. The supersaturated solid solutions formed in the milled HEAs powders are metastable phases and can cause phase transformation. 24,25,27 In addition, the ball milling produces high dislocation density and a significant volume fraction of grain boundaries, leading to a substantial amount of excess energy stored in the powders. 26,28 Accordingly, the low activation energy of the phase change caused by the excess energy significantly promotes the transition during the sintering. 29 Therefore, as shown in Fig. 3b, the phase transformation from solid solution phases (Nb-rich and Cr-rich phases) in the powders to Laves phase in the bulk alloy occurred during the SPS process.

The SEM morphologies of the sintered WMoNbCrTi alloys are presented in Fig. 4. With increased milling time, the HEAs exhibit a more homogeneous and refined microstructure. The different contrasts in Fig. 4 represent the various phases, and the corresponding compositions of these phases measured by EDS are shown in Fig. 5. Combing the results of the XRD (Fig. 3a) and the EDS (Fig. 5a andb), the dark and white zones in Fig. 4 are BCC solid solution phases, and they are enriched in Ti (Fig. 5a) and W (Fig. 5b), respectively.

The Laves phase was detected in the sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs, enriched in Cr and Nb and depleted in W, Mo and Ti, as seen in Fig. 5c. It is clear that the phase transformation from solid solution phase to Laves phase occurred during the SPS process. The type of phase in the HEAs is strongly dependent on the difference in the atomic size, and the great difference in the atomic radius could promote the formation of the compound. 30 In general, the composition of the Laves phase in a binary system is described by the formula AB 2 , where the atomic size of element A is larger than that of element B. As reported by Zhang et al. 31 the Cr-rich Laves phase was described as Cr 2 Nb in the CoCrMoNbTi alloy. It was also reported that the Laves phase was described by the formula (Nb,Ti)(Al,Cr,V) 2 in the NbTiAlCrV system. 8,32 In the refractory WMoNbCrTi system, the binary systems of Nb-Ti, Nb-W, Nb-Mo, Cr-W and Cr-Mo could form infinite solid solution, but the binary systems of Cr-Nb and Cr-Ti could form Laves phases, and the phase stability of Cr-Nb is better than that of Cr-Ti. 33 In the WMoNbCrTi system, the differences in atomic radius between Nb (150 Pm) and Cr (128 Pm) caused lattice distortion, which would destabilize the Nb-rich and Cr-rich solid solution phases and promote the formation of the Laves phase during the SPS process. According to the results of the XRD (Fig. 3) and EDS (Fig. 5c), the Laves phase in the WMoNbCrTi system could be defined as (Nb, Ti)(Cr, Mo, W) 2 .

div.head: Density of the Sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs
div.p: According to the rule of mixtures, the calculated theoretical density for the WMoNbCrTi HEA is 9.92 g/cm 3 . Figure 6a shows the relative density of the WMoNbCrTi HEAs SPSed from the different powders. It is clear that, as the milling time increased from 5 h to 40 h, the relative density of the HEAs dropped slightly from 98.8% to 97.5%. This phenomenon is often found in the powder metallurgy materials. The decrease in the relative density could be attributed to the work hardening of the powders milled for a long time, which made the powders difficult to sinter. 34 Hardness and Fracture Toughness of the Sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs Figure 6b shows the Vickers hardness and fracture toughness of the various HEAs. As the milling time increased from 5 h to 40 h, the hardness of the HEAs first increased and then decreased, and it reached the maximum value of 10.40 GPa in the 30-HEAs. Three main reasons contributed to the maximum hardness in the 30-HEA: (1) the workhardening effect in the HEA powders milled for a long time, 35 (2) the precipitation strengthening effect owing to the largest amount of Laves phase distributed in the matrix of solid solution and (3) grain size refinement of the alloy sintered with the long-time milling powders. 36 In addition, the fracture toughness of the HEAs exhibits an opposite trend to the hardness. The 5-HEAs exhibited a maximum fracture toughness value of 7.16 MPa m 1/2 , which is about 40% higher than that of the 30-HEAs. The lowest fracture toughness for the 30-HEAs is also attributed to the largest amount of the brittle Laves phase in the alloys (Table II).

div.head: Compressive Properties of the Sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs
div.p: The compressive stress-strain (r-e) curves, compressive strength and fracture strain for the WMoNbCrTi HEAs tested at room temperature are shown in Fig. 7. The results show that the milling duration of powders has a considerable influence on the compressive strength and plasticity of the HEAs. The yield strength and fracture strength of the 5-HEAs reached the values of 2492 MPa and 2765 MPa, and the corresponding compressive strains were 5.6% and 9.8%, respectively, which are remarkably superior to the refractory HEAs fabricated by the vacuum arc melting. 11 The highest compressive strength of the HEA is attributed to the 5 h milling powder having softer and irregular particles, which are easy to contact and deform during the SPS process. 37 In addition, the highest density of the HEA contributes to the better compressive properties. The change trend of the compressive strength for the alloys (10-HEAs, 20-HEAs, 30-HEAs and 40-HEAs) is consistent with the hardness. This is also due to the increase in the amount of Laves phase, small grain size and solidification hardening effect. 38 The fracture surface morphologies of the 5-HEAs and 30-HEAs are shown in Fig. 8. The failure surface of the 5-HEAs revealed a mixed mode of transgranular and intergranular fracture. However, the predominant fracture mode of the 30-HEAs is intergranular fracture (Fig. 8b). Three main factors contributed to the highest compressive strength and ductility for the 5-HEAs. First, the 5-HEAs exhibited the highest relative density compared with that of the other alloys. Second, with increasing milling time, the increasing amount of the Laves phase in the HEAs resulted in a dramatic decrease in the compressive strain. Third, it is hard to weaken the grain boundary for the 5-HEAs under external force because of the least contamination of the 5 h milling powders.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: Refractory WMoNbCrTi HEAs were SPSed using powders ball milled for various times. The microstructure and mechanical properties of the sintered HEAs are strongly dependent on the milling times of the powders. The following conclusions can be made.

1. Most Ti and Mo elements have dissolved into the other elements during the MA process. The milled powders are mainly composed of three BCC solid solution phases, including W-rich, Nb-rich and Cr-rich solid solutions, respectively. 2. The sintered WMoNbCrTi HEAs consist of two BCC solid solution phases (W-rich and Ti-rich) and a Laves phase. The Ti-rich solid solution and Laves phase are distributed homogeneously in the matrix of W-rich solid solution. The HEAs sintered from the long-time milling powders exhibit a homogeneous and refined microstructure. 3. The WMoNbCrTi HEA, sintered from the 30 h milling powder, exhibits the highest hardness value of 10.40 GPa, which is mainly attributed to the solid solution strengthening, Laves phase strengthening and grain refinement. 4. The WMoNbCrTi HEA, sintered from the 5 h milling powder, exhibits the highest fracture toughness (7.16 MPa m 1/2 ), yield strength (2492 MPa), fracture strength (2765 MPa) and fracture strain (9.8%), respectively. MA-SPS is a good method to fabricate refractory HEAs with controllable mechanical properties.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. SEM morphologies and particles size of the various HEAs powders: (a) 0-HEAs; (b) 5-HEAs; (c) 10-HEAs; (d) 20-HEAs; (e) 30-HEAs; (f) 40-HEAs; (g) particle size as a function of the milling times.

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. XRD patterns of the sintered HEAs and 30 h milling powder: (a) bulk alloys sintered from the powders milled for different times; (b) 30 h milling powder and the corresponding bulk alloy.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. SEM morphologies of the various bulk HEAs: (a) 5-HEAs (SE); (b) 10-HEAs (SE); (c) 20-HEAs (SE); (d) 30-HEAs (SE); (e) 40-HEAs (SE); (f) 40-HEAs (BSE).

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. EDS of the different phases in Fig. 4: (a) Ti-rich phase; (b) W-rich phase; (c) Laves phase.

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 6. Relative densities and mechanical properties of the various bulk HEAs: (a) relative densities; (b) hardness and fracture toughness.

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. Compressive properties of the various bulk HEAs: (a) compressive stress-strain curves; (b) compressive strength; (c) compressive fracture strain.

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. SEM images of the fracture surface for the bulk HEAs: (a) 5-HEAs; (b) 30-HEAs.
